responses.content: We have 3 hyperscale customers shipping in volume today. Beyond that, we have deeply engaged with 4 additional hyperscalers (partners) to develop custom accelerators to train their next-generation frontier models. These 4 are not included in our estimated SAM of $60B-$90B in fiscal 2027. These engagements take time; typically 1.5 years from engagement to the first chip, and another 6 months to a year to reach scale production.

Q1 AI revenue was $4.1B, up 77% YoY, beating guidance of $3.8B driven by stronger networking shipments. We expect Q2 AI revenue to grow to $4.4B, up 44% YoY. Total semiconductor revenue for Q2 is expected to be $8.4B, up 17% YoY.

We are stepping up R&D on two fronts: 1) Pushing technology for next-gen accelerators, taping out the industry's first 2nm AI XPU with 3.5D packaging targeting 10,000 teraflops. 2) Scaling clusters to 1 million XPUs by doubling the radix capacity of Tomahawk 5 and taping out the 100T Tomahawk 6 switch with 1.6T bandwidth.

Non-AI semiconductor revenue was $4.1B in Q1, down 9% sequentially due to seasonal wireless decline. Broadband showed double-digit sequential recovery from a bottom in Q4 '24. Server storage expected to be up high single digits in Q2. Enterprise networking remains flattish working through inventory. Wireless expected to be flat YoY in Q2.

Software revenue was $6.7B, up 47% YoY. Growth driven by converting perpetual licenses to subscriptions (over 60% done) and upselling to full stack VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF). 70% of our largest 10,000 customers have adopted VCF. VCF also enables on-prem AI workloads via VMware Private AI Foundation (39 customers).

We define a design win or customer only when the product is produced and deployed at scale (volume production), not just small pilots (e.g., 5,000 units). We limit ourselves to partners who need large volume for training frontier models.
Our XPUs address both training and inference, which have different architectures. The $60B-$90B SAM includes both, though the larger portion of dollars currently comes from training.

In Q1, there was a surge in networking, shifting the mix slightly, but the long-term norm within our AI revenue is approximately 70% XPUs (accelerators) and 30% connectivity/networking. Networking is driven by performance (Ethernet, optical) to scale out clusters.
We do not have concerns regarding new regulations or AI diffusion rules impacting our 3 volume hyperscale customers.
We are too busy focusing on AI and VMware execution at this point to consider M&A.

Consolidated revenue $14.9B (+25% YoY). Adjusted EBITDA $10.1B (68% margin). Semiconductor revenue $8.2B (+11% YoY), Gross Margin 68%. Infrastructure Software revenue $6.7B (+47% YoY), Operating Margin 76%.
Consolidated R&D spend was $1.4B in Q1 and will increase in Q2, focused on 2nm AI XPU packaging and next-gen Tomahawk switches to enable scaling.
Free cash flow was $6.0B (40% of revenue). Paid $2.8B in dividends and repurchased $2B shares for tax withholding. Debt reduced by net $1.1B to $68.8B gross.
Consolidated revenue ~$14.9B (+19% YoY). Semiconductor ~$8.4B (+17% YoY). Software ~$6.5B (+23% YoY). Adjusted EBITDA ~66%.

analyst_questions.question: Can you talk about the trend with the 4 new customers/partners? Can they be as big as the current 3? What does it say about the custom silicon trend?
Can you profile the second half step-up in AI revenue relative to the first half? Has the profile changed favorably or less favorably?
Are you seeing disruption from tariffs or DeepSeek dynamics? Should we expect bigger changes from Broadcom as a result?
How do you view the conversion ratio from design/engagement to actual deployment at scale?
Is there any concern about new AI diffusion rules impacting your 3 volume customers?
What happens to your opportunity if the mix moves more towards inference? Does it favor GPUs over XPUs?
When customers select between switch ASIC providers vs compute providers for networking, what are the key decision points? Why Ethernet?
Do the 4 new engagements add to the 7 million XPU unit number previously mentioned for 2027, or do they just fill it?
How do you manage differentiation/IP sharing across 6+ mega scale customers who all want to differentiate?
How do you see greenfield scale-up opportunities playing out (optical vs copper)? Where are OpEx dollars going?
How much was networking up sequentially? Any thoughts on M&A?
